{"pk": 3, "path": "000100010001", "depth": 3, "numchild": 0, "title": "Seagrid Home", "draft_title": "Seagrid Home", "slug": "seagrid-home", "content_type": 28, "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "url_path": "/home/seagrid-home/", "owner": 2, "seo_title": "", "show_in_menus": false, "search_description": "", "go_live_at": null, "expire_at": null, "expired": false, "locked": false, "first_published_at": null, "last_published_at": null, "latest_revision_created_at": null, "live_revision": null, "announcement_text": "Free American Chemical Society (ACS) Workshop on Science Gateways, New Orleans, LA, Mar 20, 2018", "announcement_link": "https://sciencegateways.org/acs2018", "image": 14, "hero_text": null, "hero_cta": null, "hero_cta_link": null, "body": "[{\"type\": \"heading_block\", \"value\": {\"heading_text\": \"Hey there this is body\", \"size\": \"h2\"}, \"id\": \"30d2e278-4f68-429e-bff8-79bf94075aa1\"}]", "site_logo": 4, "features_text": "

The Science and Engineering Applications Grid (SEAGrid) empowers researchers to easily use scientific applications deployed across a wide range of supercomputers, campus clusters, and computing cloud. SEAGrid features both a powerful desktop client and go-anywhere Web application. SEAGrid helps scientist create model inputs, simplifies access to computing resources, enables visualizations of outputs, and provides archives for simulation data.

", "feature_logo_1": 1, "feature_1_title": "Computational Chemistry", "feature_1_text": "

Optimize and characterize molecular and periodic structures and predict thermodynamics and kinetics using computational chemistry applications using Ab initio, Semi-empirical, Force-field based codes such as Gaussian, Gamess, Tinker, DFTB+.

", "feature_logo_2": 6, "feature_2_title": "Molecular Dynamics (MD)", "feature_2_text": "

Time evolution of large material and biological systems to predict dynamic structural and energetic characteristics using Applications such as Lammps, Amber, NAMD using mostly empirical force fields including reaction force fields.

", "feature_logo_3": 5, "feature_3_title": "Structural Mechanics", "feature_3_text": "

Finite element analysis of engineering structures and components for modeling static and low-speed dynamic events both in the time and frequency domain using applications such as Abaqus.

", "feature_logo_4": 2, "feature_4_title": "Fluid Dynamics", "feature_4_text": "

Modeling flow of gases and liquids under various conditions using applications such as Nek5000 and OpenFOAM.

", "custom_body_message": "

For a full list of current SEAGrid supported applications and computing resources, see SEAGrid Applications.

", "banner_image": 15}

{"pk": 5, "path": "0001000100010001", "depth": 4, "numchild": 0, "title": "About Seagrid", "draft_title": "About Seagrid", "slug": "about-seagrid", "content_type": 30, "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "url_path": "/home/seagrid-home/about-seagrid/", "owner": 2, "seo_title": "", "show_in_menus": false, "search_description": "", "go_live_at": null, "expire_at": null, "expired": false, "locked": false, "first_published_at": null, "last_published_at": null, "latest_revision_created_at": null, "live_revision": null, "about_title": "About the Project", "person_logo": 8, "person_occupation": "Principal Investigator", "person_name": "Dr. Sudhakar Pamidighantam", "body": "[{\"type\": \"paragraph_block\", \"value\": \"

The SEAGrid science gateway is led by Dr. Sudhakar Pamidighantam and powered by the NSF-funded SciGaP project. This gateway is an agile platform suitable for both research and teaching in science and engineering disciplines.

Bio: Dr. Pamidighantam is a senior member of the Science Gateways Research Center at Indiana University. Dr. Pamidighantam had been a senior research scientist at NCSA at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign supporting computational chemistry and science gateways development in support of molecular sciences faculty. He serves XSEDE organization as an ECSS consultant and conducts research in computational chemistry. See here for Dr. Pamidighantam\\u2019s Google Scholar profile.

Usage: SEAGrid has been in operation since 2005 and serves more than 600 scientists and students under 320 projects. Over this time, SEAGrid has supported and enabled more than 120 publications, 50 conference presentations, at least 13 graduate MS and Ph.D. theses. Since April 2015, SEAGrid has served close to 11M XD SUs to support almost 25,000 jobs.

Support: SEAGrid currently supported by NSF Grant #1339774. Previous NSF support includes awards The SEAGrid gateway is a production community cyberinfrastructure resource developed under the NSF Middleware Initiative (NMI: Deployment) grant and supported by additional advanced support through XSEDE ASTA and ECSS program activities. An OGCE [5] project funded by NSF enabled the SEAGrid gateway to adapt sustainable middleware.

Cite:

Citing SEAGrid in academic papers helps us show impact. If you use SEAGrid in your research please help by including the following citation information and acknowledgement in your paper.

SEAGrid (http:www.seagrid.org)[*] is acknowledged for computational resources and services for the selected results used in this publication.

* (a) S. Pamidighantama, S Nakandala, E. Abeysinghe, C Wimalasena, S. Rathnayakae, S. Marru, M. Pierce, Community Science Exemplars in SEAGrid Science Gateway: Apache Airavata Based Implementation of Advanced Infrastructure, Procedia Computer Science Volume 80, 2016, Pages 1927\\u20131939

(b) N. Shen, Y. Fan, S. Pamidighantam, E-Science Infrastructures for Molecular Modeling and Parametrization, Journal of Computational Science 5 (2014), pp. 576-589; DOI information: 10.1016/j.jocs.2014.01.005

(c) R. Dooley, K. Milfeld, C. Guiang, S. Pamidighantam, G. Allen, From Proposal to Production: Lessons Learned Developing the Computational Chemistry Grid Cyberinfrastructure, Journal of Grid Computing, 2006, 4, 195-208.

(d) K. Milfeld, C. Guiang, S. Pamidighantam, J. Giuliani. Cluster Computing through an Application-oriented Computational Chemistry Grid. Proceedings of the 2005 Linux Clusters: The HPC Revolution, Apr. 2005.

(e) This work used the Extreme Science and Engineering Discovery Environment (XSEDE), which is supported by National Science Foundation grant number OCI-1053575.

Get BibTex

\", \"id\": \"c61f5124-0a84-4488-b088-f5e533955708\"}]", "contact_mail": "pamidigs@iu.edu", "contact_phone": null, "contact_website": null}

The SEAGrid science gateway is led by Dr. Sudhakar Pamidighantam and powered by the NSF-funded SciGaP project. This gateway is an agile platform suitable for both research and teaching in science and engineering disciplines.

Bio: Dr. Pamidighantam is a senior member of the Science Gateways Research Center at Indiana University. Dr. Pamidighantam had been a senior research scientist at NCSA at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign supporting computational chemistry and science gateways development in support of molecular sciences faculty. He serves XSEDE organization as an ECSS consultant and conducts research in computational chemistry. See here for Dr. Pamidighantam\\u2019s Google Scholar profile.

Usage: SEAGrid has been in operation since 2005 and serves more than 600 scientists and students under 320 projects. Over this time, SEAGrid has supported and enabled more than 120 publications, 50 conference presentations, at least 13 graduate MS and Ph.D. theses. Since April 2015, SEAGrid has served close to 11M XD SUs to support almost 25,000 jobs.

Support: SEAGrid currently supported by NSF Grant #1339774. Previous NSF support includes awards The SEAGrid gateway is a production community cyberinfrastructure resource developed under the NSF Middleware Initiative (NMI: Deployment) grant and supported by additional advanced support through XSEDE ASTA and ECSS program activities. An OGCE [5] project funded by NSF enabled the SEAGrid gateway to adapt sustainable middleware.

\", \"id\": \"6528d211-936d-41a0-9966-ef49ae96850a\"}]", "documentation_title": "Training and Documentation", "top_body": "

SEAGrid Portal Vs GridChem Desktop Client

SEAGrid Gateway has evolved from initial focus in Chemistry (GridChem) encompassing broader Science and Engineering Applications. In addition to the desktop client, SEAGrid provides a Web Browser based gateway access. The SEAGrid gateway is in active development and we welcome you to try the pre-production alpha release and provide feedback.

Note: For production usage, we recommend using the GridChem Desktop client.

", "bottom_body": "

SGCI-MOLSSI Workshop at the ACS National Meeting, New Orleans, Mar 19-22,2018

ICCS 2017 International Conference on Computational Science

", "focus_text": "

For detailed documentation on using the GridChem production client or SEAGrid Web Portal, please visit the

SEAGrid Wiki

"}

{"pk": 5, "path": "0001000100010001", "depth": 4, "numchild": 0, "title": "About", "draft_title": "About", "slug": "about", "content_type": 30, "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "url_path": "/home/seagrid-home/about/", "owner": 2, "seo_title": "about", "show_in_menus": true, "search_description": "", "go_live_at": null, "expire_at": null, "expired": false, "locked": false, "first_published_at": "2018-03-13T23:20:37.661Z", "last_published_at": "2018-03-14T03:41:47.352Z", "latest_revision_created_at": "2018-03-14T03:41:47.328Z", "live_revision": 20, "about_title": "About the Project", "person_logo": 8, "person_occupation": "Principal Investigator", "person_name": "Dr. Sudhakar Pamidighantam", "body": "[{\"type\": \"paragraph_block\", \"value\": {\"custom_class\": \"\", \"body\": \"

The SEAGrid science gateway is led by Dr. Sudhakar Pamidighantam and powered by the NSF-funded SciGaP project. This gateway is an agile platform suitable for both research and teaching in science and engineering disciplines.

Bio: Dr. Pamidighantam is a senior member of the Science Gateways Research Center at Indiana University. Dr. Pamidighantam had been a senior research scientist at NCSA at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign supporting computational chemistry and science gateways development in support of molecular sciences faculty. He serves XSEDE organization as an ECSS consultant and conducts research in computational chemistry. See here for Dr. Pamidighantam\\u2019s Google Scholar profile.

Usage: SEAGrid has been in operation since 2005 and serves more than 600 scientists and students under 320 projects. Over this time, SEAGrid has supported and enabled more than 120 publications, 50 conference presentations, at least 13 graduate MS and Ph.D. theses. Since April 2015, SEAGrid has served close to 11M XD SUs to support almost 25,000 jobs.

Support: SEAGrid currently supported by NSF Grant #1339774. Previous NSF support includes awards The SEAGrid gateway is a production community cyberinfrastructure resource developed under the NSF Middleware Initiative (NMI: Deployment) grant and supported by additional advanced support through XSEDE ASTA and ECSS program activities. An OGCE [5] project funded by NSF enabled the SEAGrid gateway to adapt sustainable middleware.

Cite:

Citing SEAGrid in academic papers helps us show impact. If you use SEAGrid in your research please help by including the following citation information and acknowledgement in your paper.

SEAGrid (http:www.seagrid.org)[*] is acknowledged for computational resources and services for the selected results used in this publication.

* (a) S. Pamidighantama, S Nakandala, E. Abeysinghe, C Wimalasena, S. Rathnayakae, S. Marru, M. Pierce, Community Science Exemplars in SEAGrid Science Gateway: Apache Airavata Based Implementation of Advanced Infrastructure, Procedia Computer Science Volume 80, 2016, Pages 1927\\u20131939

(b) N. Shen, Y. Fan, S. Pamidighantam, E-Science Infrastructures for Molecular Modeling and Parametrization, Journal of Computational Science 5 (2014), pp. 576-589; DOI information: 10.1016/j.jocs.2014.01.005

(c) R. Dooley, K. Milfeld, C. Guiang, S. Pamidighantam, G. Allen, From Proposal to Production: Lessons Learned Developing the Computational Chemistry Grid Cyberinfrastructure, Journal of Grid Computing, 2006, 4, 195-208.

(d) K. Milfeld, C. Guiang, S. Pamidighantam, J. Giuliani. Cluster Computing through an Application-oriented Computational Chemistry Grid. Proceedings of the 2005 Linux Clusters: The HPC Revolution, Apr. 2005.

(e) This work used the Extreme Science and Engineering Discovery Environment (XSEDE), which is supported by National Science Foundation grant number OCI-1053575.

distributed computing resources including local clusters, supercomputers, national grids,
academic and commercial clouds. Airavata builds on general concepts of service oriented computing,
distributed messaging, and workflow composition and orchestration. Airavata bundles a server package

{"pk": 10, "path": "0001000100010005", "depth": 4, "numchild": 0, "title": "About New", "draft_title": "About New", "slug": "about-new", "content_type": 34, "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "url_path": "/home/seagrid-home/about-new/", "owner": 2, "seo_title": "", "show_in_menus": false, "search_description": "", "go_live_at": null, "expire_at": null, "expired": false, "locked": false, "first_published_at": null, "last_published_at": null, "latest_revision_created_at": null, "live_revision": null, "row": [{"pk": 4, "sort_order": 0, "body": "[{\"type\": \"bootstrap_card\", \"value\": {\"card_width\": \"18\", \"is_card_img\": true, \"card_img\": 8, \"card_title\": \"Principal Investigator\", \"card_text\": \"

Dr. Sudhakar Pamidighantam

Contact: pamidigs@iu.edu

\", \"card_bg_color\": \"bg-warning\", \"btn_text\": \"Visit my Site\", \"btn_color\": \"btn-success\", \"btn_link\": \"https://www.google.com\", \"custom_class\": \"mx-auto col-md-2\"}, \"id\": \"65a2f93a-9e02-42f5-a7b5-8b69e459d1d2\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph_block\", \"value\": {\"custom_class\": \"col-md-6\", \"body\": \"

The SEAGrid science gateway is led by Dr. Sudhakar Pamidighantam and powered by the NSF-funded SciGaPproject. This gateway is an agile platform suitable for both research and teaching in science and engineering disciplines.

Bio: Dr. Pamidighantam is a senior member of the Science Gateways Research Center at Indiana University. Dr. Pamidighantam had been a senior research scientist at NCSA at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign supporting computational chemistry and science gateways development in support of molecular sciences faculty. He serves XSEDE organization as an ECSS consultant and conducts research in computational chemistry. See here for Dr. Pamidighantam\\u2019s Google Scholar profile.

Usage: SEAGrid has been in operation since 2005 and serves more than 600 scientists and students under 320 projects. Over this time, SEAGrid has supported and enabled more than 120 publications, 50 conference presentations, at least 13 graduate MS and Ph.D. theses. Since April 2015, SEAGrid has served close to 11M XD SUs to support almost 25,000 jobs.

Support: SEAGrid currently supported by NSF Grant #1339774. Previous NSF support includes awards The SEAGrid gateway is a production community cyberinfrastructure resource developed under the NSF Middleware Initiative (NMI: Deployment) grant and supported by additional advanced support through XSEDE ASTA and ECSS program activities. An OGCE [5] project funded by NSF enabled the SEAGrid gateway to adapt sustainable middleware.

Cite:

Citing SEAGrid in academic papers helps us show impact. If you use SEAGrid in your research please help by including the following citation information and acknowledgement in your paper.

SEAGrid (http:www.seagrid.org)[*] is acknowledged for computational resources and services for the selected results used in this publication.

* (a) S. Pamidighantama, S Nakandala, E. Abeysinghe, C Wimalasena, S. Rathnayakae, S. Marru, M. Pierce, Community Science Exemplars in SEAGrid Science Gateway: Apache Airavata Based Implementation of Advanced Infrastructure, Procedia Computer Science Volume 80, 2016, Pages 1927\\u20131939

(b) N. Shen, Y. Fan, S. Pamidighantam, E-Science Infrastructures for Molecular Modeling and Parametrization, Journal of Computational Science 5 (2014), pp. 576-589; DOI information: 10.1016/j.jocs.2014.01.005

(c) R. Dooley, K. Milfeld, C. Guiang, S. Pamidighantam, G. Allen, From Proposal to Production: Lessons Learned Developing the Computational Chemistry Grid Cyberinfrastructure, Journal of Grid Computing, 2006, 4, 195-208.

(d) K. Milfeld, C. Guiang, S. Pamidighantam, J. Giuliani. Cluster Computing through an Application-oriented Computational Chemistry Grid. Proceedings of the 2005 Linux Clusters: The HPC Revolution, Apr. 2005.

(e) This work used the Extreme Science and Engineering Discovery Environment (XSEDE), which is supported by National Science Foundation grant number OCI-1053575.

Get BibTex

\"}, \"id\": \"97cfb3a8-80a5-4e0f-8c1f-e40057581061\"}]", "page": 10}]}

{"pk": 10, "path": "0001000100010005", "depth": 4, "numchild": 0, "title": "About New", "draft_title": "About New", "slug": "about-new", "content_type": 34, "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "url_path": "/home/seagrid-home/about-new/", "owner": 2, "seo_title": "", "show_in_menus": false, "search_description": "", "go_live_at": null, "expire_at": null, "expired": false, "locked": false, "first_published_at": "2018-03-20T20:05:26.098Z", "last_published_at": "2018-03-20T20:06:22.616Z", "latest_revision_created_at": "2018-03-20T20:06:22.589Z", "live_revision": 125, "row": [{"pk": 4, "sort_order": 0, "body": "[{\"type\": \"bootstrap_card\", \"value\": {\"card_width\": \"18\", \"is_card_img\": true, \"card_img\": 8, \"card_title\": \"Principal Investigator\", \"card_text\": \"

Dr. Sudhakar Pamidighantam

Contact: pamidigs@iu.edu

\", \"card_bg_color\": \"bg-warning\", \"btn_text\": \"Visit my Site\", \"btn_color\": \"btn-success\", \"btn_link\": \"https://www.google.com\", \"custom_class\": \"mt-4 col-md-4\"}, \"id\": \"65a2f93a-9e02-42f5-a7b5-8b69e459d1d2\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph_block\", \"value\": {\"custom_class\": \"mt-4 col-md-8\", \"body\": \"

The SEAGrid science gateway is led by Dr. Sudhakar Pamidighantam and powered by the NSF-funded SciGaPproject. This gateway is an agile platform suitable for both research and teaching in science and engineering disciplines.

Bio: Dr. Pamidighantam is a senior member of the Science Gateways Research Center at Indiana University. Dr. Pamidighantam had been a senior research scientist at NCSA at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign supporting computational chemistry and science gateways development in support of molecular sciences faculty. He serves XSEDE organization as an ECSS consultant and conducts research in computational chemistry. See here for Dr. Pamidighantam\\u2019s Google Scholar profile.

Usage: SEAGrid has been in operation since 2005 and serves more than 600 scientists and students under 320 projects. Over this time, SEAGrid has supported and enabled more than 120 publications, 50 conference presentations, at least 13 graduate MS and Ph.D. theses. Since April 2015, SEAGrid has served close to 11M XD SUs to support almost 25,000 jobs.

Support: SEAGrid currently supported by NSF Grant #1339774. Previous NSF support includes awards The SEAGrid gateway is a production community cyberinfrastructure resource developed under the NSF Middleware Initiative (NMI: Deployment) grant and supported by additional advanced support through XSEDE ASTA and ECSS program activities. An OGCE [5] project funded by NSF enabled the SEAGrid gateway to adapt sustainable middleware.

Cite:

Citing SEAGrid in academic papers helps us show impact. If you use SEAGrid in your research please help by including the following citation information and acknowledgement in your paper.

SEAGrid (http:www.seagrid.org)[*] is acknowledged for computational resources and services for the selected results used in this publication.

* (a) S. Pamidighantama, S Nakandala, E. Abeysinghe, C Wimalasena, S. Rathnayakae, S. Marru, M. Pierce, Community Science Exemplars in SEAGrid Science Gateway: Apache Airavata Based Implementation of Advanced Infrastructure, Procedia Computer Science Volume 80, 2016, Pages 1927\\u20131939

(b) N. Shen, Y. Fan, S. Pamidighantam, E-Science Infrastructures for Molecular Modeling and Parametrization, Journal of Computational Science 5 (2014), pp. 576-589; DOI information: 10.1016/j.jocs.2014.01.005

(c) R. Dooley, K. Milfeld, C. Guiang, S. Pamidighantam, G. Allen, From Proposal to Production: Lessons Learned Developing the Computational Chemistry Grid Cyberinfrastructure, Journal of Grid Computing, 2006, 4, 195-208.

(d) K. Milfeld, C. Guiang, S. Pamidighantam, J. Giuliani. Cluster Computing through an Application-oriented Computational Chemistry Grid. Proceedings of the 2005 Linux Clusters: The HPC Revolution, Apr. 2005.

(e) This work used the Extreme Science and Engineering Discovery Environment (XSEDE), which is supported by National Science Foundation grant number OCI-1053575.

Get BibTex

\", \"card_bg_color\": \"bg-light\", \"btn_text\": \"Visit my Site\", \"btn_color\": \"btn-success\", \"btn_link\": \"https://www.google.com\", \"custom_class\": \"mt-4 mx-auto col-md-2\"}, \"id\": \"65a2f93a-9e02-42f5-a7b5-8b69e459d1d2\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph_block\", \"value\": {\"custom_class\": \"mt-4 col-md-8 mx-auto\", \"body\": \"

The SEAGrid science gateway is led by Dr. Sudhakar Pamidighantam and powered by the NSF-funded SciGaPproject. This gateway is an agile platform suitable for both research and teaching in science and engineering disciplines.

Bio: Dr. Pamidighantam is a senior member of the Science Gateways Research Center at Indiana University. Dr. Pamidighantam had been a senior research scientist at NCSA at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign supporting computational chemistry and science gateways development in support of molecular sciences faculty. He serves XSEDE organization as an ECSS consultant and conducts research in computational chemistry. See here for Dr. Pamidighantam\\u2019s Google Scholar profile.

Usage: SEAGrid has been in operation since 2005 and serves more than 600 scientists and students under 320 projects. Over this time, SEAGrid has supported and enabled more than 120 publications, 50 conference presentations, at least 13 graduate MS and Ph.D. theses. Since April 2015, SEAGrid has served close to 11M XD SUs to support almost 25,000 jobs.

Support: SEAGrid currently supported by NSF Grant #1339774. Previous NSF support includes awards The SEAGrid gateway is a production community cyberinfrastructure resource developed under the NSF Middleware Initiative (NMI: Deployment) grant and supported by additional advanced support through XSEDE ASTA and ECSS program activities. An OGCE [5] project funded by NSF enabled the SEAGrid gateway to adapt sustainable middleware.

Cite:

Citing SEAGrid in academic papers helps us show impact. If you use SEAGrid in your research please help by including the following citation information and acknowledgement in your paper.

SEAGrid (http:www.seagrid.org)[*] is acknowledged for computational resources and services for the selected results used in this publication.

(c) R. Dooley, K. Milfeld, C. Guiang, S. Pamidighantam, G. Allen, From Proposal to Production: Lessons Learned Developing the Computational Chemistry Grid Cyberinfrastructure, Journal of Grid Computing, 2006, 4, 195-208.

(d) K. Milfeld, C. Guiang, S. Pamidighantam, J. Giuliani. Cluster Computing through an Application-oriented Computational Chemistry Grid. Proceedings of the 2005 Linux Clusters: The HPC Revolution, Apr. 2005.

(e) This work used the Extreme Science and Engineering Discovery Environment (XSEDE), which is supported by National Science Foundation grant number OCI-1053575.

XSEDE is a single virtual system that scientists can use to interactively share computing resources, data and expertise. People around the world use these resources and services \\u2014 things like supercomputers, collections of data and new tools \\u2014 to improve our planet.

\", \"card_bg_color\": \"bg-light\", \"btn_text\": \"Visit the site\", \"btn_color\": \"btn-success\", \"btn_link\": \"https://www.xsede.org/\", \"custom_class\": \"col-md-2 mx-auto\"}, \"id\": \"5bd11fe1-d7dc-4d43-968c-cf1a8bdbe0fb\"}, {\"type\": \"bootstrap_jumbotron\", \"value\": {\"title\": \"Apache Airavata\", \"body\": \"

Apache Airavata, a software framework to executing and managing computational jobs on
distributed computing resources including local clusters, supercomputers, national grids,
academic and commercial clouds.

Airavata builds on general concepts of service oriented computing,
distributed messaging, and workflow composition and orchestration. Airavata bundles a server package
with an API, client software development Kits and a general purpose reference UI implementation - Apache Airavata PHP reference gateway.

\", \"button_text\": \"Visit the site\", \"button_link\": \"https://github.com/apache/airavata\", \"button_color\": \"btn-warning\", \"button_size\": \"btn-lg\", \"custom_class\": \"col-md-8\"}, \"id\": \"dece2ba1-595f-46ae-bb41-e5ae5dd90c3e\"}]", "page": 11}]}

Features

The Science and Engineering Applications Grid (SEAGrid) empowers researchers to easily use scientific applications deployed across a wide range of supercomputers, campus clusters, and computing cloud. SEAGrid features both a powerful desktop client and go-anywhere Web application. SEAGrid helps scientist create model inputs, simplifies access to computing resources, enables visualizations of outputs, and provides archives for simulation data.

\", \"card_bg_color\": \"bg-light\", \"btn_text\": \"Visit the site\", \"btn_color\": \"btn-success\", \"btn_link\": \"https://www.xsede.org/\", \"custom_class\": \"mt-4 col-md-2 mx-auto\"}, \"id\": \"5bd11fe1-d7dc-4d43-968c-cf1a8bdbe0fb\"}, {\"type\": \"bootstrap_jumbotron\", \"value\": {\"title\": \"Apache Airavata\", \"body\": \"

Apache Airavata, a software framework to executing and managing computational jobs on
distributed computing resources including local clusters, supercomputers, national grids,
academic and commercial clouds.

Airavata builds on general concepts of service oriented computing,
distributed messaging, and workflow composition and orchestration. Airavata bundles a server package
with an API, client software development Kits and a general purpose reference UI implementation - Apache Airavata PHP reference gateway.

Features

The Science and Engineering Applications Grid (SEAGrid) empowers researchers to easily use scientific applications deployed across a wide range of supercomputers, campus clusters, and computing cloud. SEAGrid features both a powerful desktop client and go-anywhere Web application. SEAGrid helps scientist create model inputs, simplifies access to computing resources, enables visualizations of outputs, and provides archives for simulation data.

{"pk": 10, "path": "0001000100010005", "depth": 4, "numchild": 0, "title": "About New", "draft_title": "About New", "slug": "about-new", "content_type": 34, "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "url_path": "/home/seagrid-home/about-new/", "owner": 2, "seo_title": "", "show_in_menus": false, "search_description": "", "go_live_at": null, "expire_at": null, "expired": false, "locked": false, "first_published_at": "2018-03-20T20:05:26.098Z", "last_published_at": "2018-03-20T20:20:59.570Z", "latest_revision_created_at": "2018-03-20T20:20:59.541Z", "live_revision": 142, "row": [{"pk": 4, "sort_order": 0, "body": "[{\"type\": \"bootstrap_card\", \"value\": {\"card_width\": 18, \"is_card_img\": true, \"card_img\": 8, \"card_title\": \"Principal Investigator\", \"card_text\": \"

Dr. Sudhakar Pamidighantam

Contact: pamidigs@iu.edu

\", \"card_bg_color\": \"bg-light\", \"btn_text\": \"Visit my Site\", \"btn_color\": \"btn-success\", \"btn_link\": \"https://www.google.com\", \"custom_class\": \"mt-4 mx-auto col-md-2\"}, \"id\": \"65a2f93a-9e02-42f5-a7b5-8b69e459d1d2\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph_block\", \"value\": {\"custom_class\": \"mt-4 col-md-8 mx-auto\", \"body\": \"

The SEAGrid science gateway is led by Dr. Sudhakar Pamidighantam and powered by the NSF-funded SciGaPproject. This gateway is an agile platform suitable for both research and teaching in science and engineering disciplines.

Bio: Dr. Pamidighantam is a senior member of the Science Gateways Research Center at Indiana University. Dr. Pamidighantam had been a senior research scientist at NCSA at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign supporting computational chemistry and science gateways development in support of molecular sciences faculty. He serves XSEDE organization as an ECSS consultant and conducts research in computational chemistry. See here for Dr. Pamidighantam\\u2019s Google Scholar profile.

Usage: SEAGrid has been in operation since 2005 and serves more than 600 scientists and students under 320 projects. Over this time, SEAGrid has supported and enabled more than 120 publications, 50 conference presentations, at least 13 graduate MS and Ph.D. theses. Since April 2015, SEAGrid has served close to 11M XD SUs to support almost 25,000 jobs.

Support: SEAGrid currently supported by NSF Grant #1339774. Previous NSF support includes awards The SEAGrid gateway is a production community cyberinfrastructure resource developed under the NSF Middleware Initiative (NMI: Deployment) grant and supported by additional advanced support through XSEDE ASTA and ECSS program activities. An OGCE [5] project funded by NSF enabled the SEAGrid gateway to adapt sustainable middleware.

Cite:

Citing SEAGrid in academic papers helps us show impact. If you use SEAGrid in your research please help by including the following citation information and acknowledgement in your paper.

SEAGrid (http:www.seagrid.org)[*] is acknowledged for computational resources and services for the selected results used in this publication.

* (a) S. Pamidighantama, S Nakandala, E. Abeysinghe, C Wimalasena, S. Rathnayakae, S. Marru, M. Pierce, Community Science Exemplars in SEAGrid Science Gateway: Apache Airavata Based Implementation of Advanced Infrastructure, Procedia Computer Science Volume 80, 2016, Pages 1927\\u20131939

(b) N. Shen, Y. Fan, S. Pamidighantam, E-Science Infrastructures for Molecular Modeling and Parametrization, Journal of Computational Science 5 (2014), pp. 576-589; DOI information: 10.1016/j.jocs.2014.01.005

(c) R. Dooley, K. Milfeld, C. Guiang, S. Pamidighantam, G. Allen, From Proposal to Production: Lessons Learned Developing the Computational Chemistry Grid Cyberinfrastructure, Journal of Grid Computing, 2006, 4, 195-208.

(d) K. Milfeld, C. Guiang, S. Pamidighantam, J. Giuliani. Cluster Computing through an Application-oriented Computational Chemistry Grid. Proceedings of the 2005 Linux Clusters: The HPC Revolution, Apr. 2005.

(e) This work used the Extreme Science and Engineering Discovery Environment (XSEDE), which is supported by National Science Foundation grant number OCI-1053575.

Get BibTex

{"pk": 11, "path": "0001000100010006", "depth": 4, "numchild": 0, "title": "New Home", "draft_title": "New Home", "slug": "new-home", "content_type": 34, "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "url_path": "/home/seagrid-home/new-home/", "owner": 2, "seo_title": "", "show_in_menus": false, "search_description": "", "go_live_at": null, "expire_at": null, "expired": false, "locked": false, "first_published_at": "2018-03-21T15:50:47.699Z", "last_published_at": "2018-03-21T16:47:18.030Z", "latest_revision_created_at": "2018-03-21T16:47:17.991Z", "live_revision": 168, "row": [{"pk": 6, "sort_order": 0, "body": "[{\"type\": \"bootstrap_alert\", \"value\": {\"alert_text\": \"Free American Chemical Society (ACS) Workshop on Science Gateways, New Orleans, LA, Mar 20, 2018\", \"alert_color\": \"alert-success\", \"is_link\": true, \"alert_link\": \"https://sciencegateways.org/acs2018\", \"custom_class\": \"col-md-12 mt-2\"}, \"id\": \"f6ae1dad-3a78-468c-9e7a-8aca324a4ba2\"}]", "page": 11}, {"pk": 7, "sort_order": 1, "body": "[{\"type\": \"bootstrap_carousel\", \"value\": {\"c_image1\": 14, \"c_image2\": 15, \"c_image3\": 17, \"c_image4\": 19, \"c_image5\": null, \"custom_class\": \"col-md-12\"}, \"id\": \"dd6827b6-a888-4f6b-ba16-ba0698c4006b\"}]", "page": 11}, {"pk": 8, "sort_order": 2, "body": "[{\"type\": \"bootstrap_card\", \"value\": {\"card_width\": 18, \"is_card_img\": true, \"card_img\": 11, \"card_title\": \"XSEDE\", \"card_text\": \"

XSEDE is a single virtual system that scientists can use to interactively share computing resources, data and expertise. People around the world use these resources and services \\u2014 things like supercomputers, collections of data and new tools \\u2014 to improve our planet.

\", \"card_bg_color\": \"bg-light\", \"card_text_color\": \"\", \"btn_text\": \"Visit the site\", \"btn_color\": \"btn-success\", \"btn_link\": \"https://www.xsede.org/\", \"custom_class\": \"mt-4 col-md-2 mx-auto\"}, \"id\": \"5bd11fe1-d7dc-4d43-968c-cf1a8bdbe0fb\"}, {\"type\": \"bootstrap_jumbotron\", \"value\": {\"title\": \"Apache Airavata\", \"body\": \"

Apache Airavata, a software framework to executing and managing computational jobs on
distributed computing resources including local clusters, supercomputers, national grids,
academic and commercial clouds.

Airavata builds on general concepts of service oriented computing,
distributed messaging, and workflow composition and orchestration. Airavata bundles a server package
with an API, client software development Kits and a general purpose reference UI implementation - Apache Airavata PHP reference gateway.

\", \"button_text\": \"Visit the site\", \"button_link\": \"https://github.com/apache/airavata\", \"button_color\": \"btn-warning\", \"button_size\": \"btn-lg\", \"custom_class\": \"mt-4 col-md-8 mx-auto\"}, \"id\": \"dece2ba1-595f-46ae-bb41-e5ae5dd90c3e\"}]", "page": 11}, {"pk": 9, "sort_order": 3, "body": "[{\"type\": \"paragraph_block\", \"value\": {\"custom_class\": \"col-md-12 text-center\", \"body\": \"

Features

The Science and Engineering Applications Grid (SEAGrid) empowers researchers to easily use scientific applications deployed across a wide range of supercomputers, campus clusters, and computing cloud. SEAGrid features both a powerful desktop client and go-anywhere Web application. SEAGrid helps scientist create model inputs, simplifies access to computing resources, enables visualizations of outputs, and provides archives for simulation data.

\"}, \"id\": \"ceca43aa-532f-4120-9994-d82cca1b69a1\"}]", "page": 11}, {"pk": 10, "sort_order": 4, "body": "[{\"type\": \"bootstrap_card\", \"value\": {\"card_width\": 21, \"is_card_img\": true, \"card_img\": 1, \"card_title\": \"Computational Chemistry\", \"card_text\": \"

Optimize and characterize molecular and periodic structures and predict thermodynamics and kinetics using computational chemistry applications using Ab initio, Semi-empirical, Force-field based codes such as Gaussian, Gamess, Tinker, DFTB+.

\", \"card_bg_color\": \"bg-light\", \"card_text_color\": \"\", \"btn_text\": \"\", \"btn_color\": \"\", \"btn_link\": \"\", \"custom_class\": \"col-md-3 new-home-card\"}, \"id\": \"9eb2fcbc-a0ef-4118-8996-003c5c83a154\"}, {\"type\": \"bootstrap_card\", \"value\": {\"card_width\": 21, \"is_card_img\": true, \"card_img\": 6, \"card_title\": \"Molecular Dynamics (MD)\", \"card_text\": \"

Time evolution of large material and biological systems to predict dynamic structural and energetic characteristics using Applications such as Lammps, Amber, NAMD using mostly empirical force fields including reaction force fields.

\", \"card_bg_color\": \"bg-light\", \"card_text_color\": \"\", \"btn_text\": \"\", \"btn_color\": \"\", \"btn_link\": \"\", \"custom_class\": \"col-md-3 new-home-card\"}, \"id\": \"4393fe0a-cf6f-466b-9cb8-b2d6a84dfaf9\"}, {\"type\": \"bootstrap_card\", \"value\": {\"card_width\": 21, \"is_card_img\": true, \"card_img\": 5, \"card_title\": \"Structural Mechanics\", \"card_text\": \"

Finite element analysis of engineering structures and components for modeling static and low-speed dynamic events both in the time and frequency domain using applications such as Abaqus.

\", \"card_bg_color\": \"bg-light\", \"card_text_color\": \"\", \"btn_text\": \"\", \"btn_color\": \"\", \"btn_link\": \"\", \"custom_class\": \"col-md-3 new-home-card\"}, \"id\": \"1dc1cb69-3e25-41b4-b666-a623cf46ef18\"}, {\"type\": \"bootstrap_card\", \"value\": {\"card_width\": 21, \"is_card_img\": true, \"card_img\": 2, \"card_title\": \"Fluid Dynamics\", \"card_text\": \"

Modeling flow of gases and liquids under various conditions using applications such as Nek5000 and OpenFOAM.

\", \"card_bg_color\": \"bg-light\", \"card_text_color\": \"\", \"btn_text\": \"\", \"btn_color\": \"\", \"btn_link\": \"\", \"custom_class\": \"col-md-3 new-home-card\"}, \"id\": \"186c0def-cbbd-4113-ac07-2811656ae096\"}]", "page": 11}, {"pk": 11, "sort_order": 5, "body": "[{\"type\": \"image_block\", \"value\": {\"image\": 15, \"caption\": \"Seagrid DNA\", \"width\": \"200\", \"custom_class\": \"col-md-12 new-home-banner mt-2\"}, \"id\": \"ef3e5cc7-eab4-4658-bab8-079c350e4ded\"}]", "page": 11}]}

distributed computing resources including local clusters, supercomputers, national grids,
academic and commercial clouds.

distributed messaging, and workflow composition and orchestration. Airavata bundles a server package
with an API, client software development Kits and a general purpose reference UI implementation - Apache Airavata PHP reference gateway.

Features

The Science and Engineering Applications Grid (SEAGrid) empowers researchers to easily use scientific applications deployed across a wide range of supercomputers, campus clusters, and computing cloud. SEAGrid features both a powerful desktop client and go-anywhere Web application. SEAGrid helps scientist create model inputs, simplifies access to computing resources, enables visualizations of outputs, and provides archives for simulation data.

Features

The Science and Engineering Applications Grid (SEAGrid) empowers researchers to easily use scientific applications deployed across a wide range of supercomputers, campus clusters, and computing cloud. SEAGrid features both a powerful desktop client and go-anywhere Web application. SEAGrid helps scientist create model inputs, simplifies access to computing resources, enables visualizations of outputs, and provides archives for simulation data.

{"pk": 10, "path": "0001000100010005", "depth": 4, "numchild": 0, "title": "About New", "draft_title": "About New", "slug": "about-new", "content_type": 34, "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "url_path": "/home/seagrid-home/about-new/", "owner": 2, "seo_title": "", "show_in_menus": false, "search_description": "", "go_live_at": null, "expire_at": null, "expired": false, "locked": false, "first_published_at": "2018-03-20T20:05:26.098Z", "last_published_at": "2018-03-21T17:06:52.345Z", "latest_revision_created_at": "2018-03-21T17:06:52.315Z", "live_revision": 172, "row": [{"pk": 4, "sort_order": 0, "body": "[{\"type\": \"bootstrap_card\", \"value\": {\"card_width\": 18, \"is_card_img\": true, \"card_img\": 8, \"card_img_width\": null, \"card_img_height\": null, \"card_title\": \"Principal Investigator\", \"card_text\": \"

Dr. Sudhakar Pamidighantam

Contact: pamidigs@iu.edu

\", \"card_bg_color\": \"bg-light\", \"card_text_color\": \"text-dark\", \"btn_text\": \"Visit my Site\", \"btn_color\": \"btn-warning\", \"btn_link\": \"https://www.google.com\", \"custom_class\": \"mt-4 mx-auto col-md-2\"}, \"id\": \"65a2f93a-9e02-42f5-a7b5-8b69e459d1d2\"}, {\"type\": \"paragraph_block\", \"value\": {\"custom_class\": \"mt-4 col-md-8 mx-auto\", \"body\": \"

The SEAGrid science gateway is led by Dr. Sudhakar Pamidighantam and powered by the NSF-funded SciGaPproject. This gateway is an agile platform suitable for both research and teaching in science and engineering disciplines.

Bio: Dr. Pamidighantam is a senior member of the Science Gateways Research Center at Indiana University. Dr. Pamidighantam had been a senior research scientist at NCSA at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign supporting computational chemistry and science gateways development in support of molecular sciences faculty. He serves XSEDE organization as an ECSS consultant and conducts research in computational chemistry. See here for Dr. Pamidighantam\\u2019s Google Scholar profile.

Usage: SEAGrid has been in operation since 2005 and serves more than 600 scientists and students under 320 projects. Over this time, SEAGrid has supported and enabled more than 120 publications, 50 conference presentations, at least 13 graduate MS and Ph.D. theses. Since April 2015, SEAGrid has served close to 11M XD SUs to support almost 25,000 jobs.

Support: SEAGrid currently supported by NSF Grant #1339774. Previous NSF support includes awards The SEAGrid gateway is a production community cyberinfrastructure resource developed under the NSF Middleware Initiative (NMI: Deployment) grant and supported by additional advanced support through XSEDE ASTA and ECSS program activities. An OGCE [5] project funded by NSF enabled the SEAGrid gateway to adapt sustainable middleware.

Cite:

Citing SEAGrid in academic papers helps us show impact. If you use SEAGrid in your research please help by including the following citation information and acknowledgement in your paper.

SEAGrid (http:www.seagrid.org)[*] is acknowledged for computational resources and services for the selected results used in this publication.

* (a) S. Pamidighantama, S Nakandala, E. Abeysinghe, C Wimalasena, S. Rathnayakae, S. Marru, M. Pierce, Community Science Exemplars in SEAGrid Science Gateway: Apache Airavata Based Implementation of Advanced Infrastructure, Procedia Computer Science Volume 80, 2016, Pages 1927\\u20131939

(b) N. Shen, Y. Fan, S. Pamidighantam, E-Science Infrastructures for Molecular Modeling and Parametrization, Journal of Computational Science 5 (2014), pp. 576-589; DOI information: 10.1016/j.jocs.2014.01.005

(c) R. Dooley, K. Milfeld, C. Guiang, S. Pamidighantam, G. Allen, From Proposal to Production: Lessons Learned Developing the Computational Chemistry Grid Cyberinfrastructure, Journal of Grid Computing, 2006, 4, 195-208.

(d) K. Milfeld, C. Guiang, S. Pamidighantam, J. Giuliani. Cluster Computing through an Application-oriented Computational Chemistry Grid. Proceedings of the 2005 Linux Clusters: The HPC Revolution, Apr. 2005.

(e) This work used the Extreme Science and Engineering Discovery Environment (XSEDE), which is supported by National Science Foundation grant number OCI-1053575.

Get BibTex

\"}, \"id\": \"97cfb3a8-80a5-4e0f-8c1f-e40057581061\"}]", "page": 10}]}

\", \"card_bg_color\": \"bg-light\", \"card_text_color\": \"\", \"btn_text\": \"Visit the site\", \"btn_color\": \"btn-success\", \"btn_link\": \"https://www.xsede.org/\", \"custom_class\": \"mt-4 col-md-2 mx-auto\"}, \"id\": \"5bd11fe1-d7dc-4d43-968c-cf1a8bdbe0fb\"}, {\"type\": \"bootstrap_jumbotron\", \"value\": {\"title\": \"Apache Airavata\", \"body\": \"

Apache Airavata, a software framework to executing and managing computational jobs on
distributed computing resources including local clusters, supercomputers, national grids,
academic and commercial clouds.

Airavata builds on general concepts of service oriented computing,
distributed messaging, and workflow composition and orchestration. Airavata bundles a server package
with an API, client software development Kits and a general purpose reference UI implementation - Apache Airavata PHP reference gateway.

\", \"button_text\": \"Visit the site\", \"button_link\": \"https://github.com/apache/airavata\", \"button_color\": \"btn-warning\", \"button_size\": \"btn-lg\", \"custom_class\": \"mt-4 col-md-8 mx-auto\"}, \"id\": \"dece2ba1-595f-46ae-bb41-e5ae5dd90c3e\"}]", "page": 11}, {"pk": 9, "sort_order": 3, "body": "[{\"type\": \"paragraph_block\", \"value\": {\"custom_class\": \"col-md-12 text-center\", \"body\": \"

Features

The Science and Engineering Applications Grid (SEAGrid) empowers researchers to easily use scientific applications deployed across a wide range of supercomputers, campus clusters, and computing cloud. SEAGrid features both a powerful desktop client and go-anywhere Web application. SEAGrid helps scientist create model inputs, simplifies access to computing resources, enables visualizations of outputs, and provides archives for simulation data.

SEAGrid features both a powerful desktop client and go-anywhere Web application. SEAGrid helps scientist create model inputs, simplifies access to computing resources, enables visualizations of outputs, and provides archives for simulation data.

{"pk": 3, "path": "000100010001", "depth": 3, "numchild": 6, "title": "Seagrid Home", "draft_title": "Seagrid Home", "slug": "seagrid-home", "content_type": 28, "live": true, "has_unpublished_changes": false, "url_path": "/home/seagrid-home/", "owner": 2, "seo_title": "", "show_in_menus": false, "search_description": "", "go_live_at": null, "expire_at": null, "expired": false, "locked": false, "first_published_at": "2018-03-13T19:43:21.525Z", "last_published_at": "2018-03-13T19:43:21.525Z", "latest_revision_created_at": "2018-03-13T19:43:21.496Z", "live_revision": 1, "announcement_text": "Free American Chemical Society (ACS) Workshop on Science Gateways, New Orleans, LA, Mar 20, 2018", "announcement_link": "https://sciencegateways.org/acs2018", "image": 17, "hero_text": null, "hero_cta": null, "hero_cta_link": null, "body": "[{\"type\": \"paragraph_block\", \"value\": {\"custom_class\": \"\", \"body\": \"

\"}, \"id\": \"75cbc8ad-8ecf-46a1-becc-0a4e31109342\"}]", "site_logo": 4, "features_text": "

The Science and Engineering Applications Grid (SEAGrid) empowers researchers to easily use scientific applications deployed across a wide range of supercomputers, campus clusters, and computing cloud. SEAGrid features both a powerful desktop client and go-anywhere Web application. SEAGrid helps scientist create model inputs, simplifies access to computing resources, enables visualizations of outputs, and provides archives for simulation data.

", "feature_logo_1": 1, "feature_1_title": "Computational Chemistry", "feature_1_text": "

Optimize and characterize molecular and periodic structures and predict thermodynamics and kinetics using computational chemistry applications using Ab initio, Semi-empirical, Force-field based codes such as Gaussian, Gamess, Tinker, DFTB+.

", "feature_logo_2": 6, "feature_2_title": "Molecular Dynamics (MD)", "feature_2_text": "

Time evolution of large material and biological systems to predict dynamic structural and energetic characteristics using Applications such as Lammps, Amber, NAMD using mostly empirical force fields including reaction force fields.

", "feature_logo_3": 5, "feature_3_title": "Structural Mechanics", "feature_3_text": "

Finite element analysis of engineering structures and components for modeling static and low-speed dynamic events both in the time and frequency domain using applications such as Abaqus.

", "feature_logo_4": 2, "feature_4_title": "Fluid Dynamics", "feature_4_text": "

Modeling flow of gases and liquids under various conditions using applications such as Nek5000 and OpenFOAM.

", "custom_body_message": "

For a full list of current SEAGrid supported applications and computing resources, see SEAGrid Applications.

", "banner_image": 15}

fields.announcement_text: Free American Chemical Society (ACS) Workshop on Science Gateways, New Orleans, LA, Mar 20, 2017

fields.features_text: The Science and Engineering Applications Grid (SEAGrid) empowers researchers to easily use scientific applications deployed across a wide range of supercomputers, campus clusters, and computing cloud. SEAGrid features both a powerful desktop client and go-anywhere Web application. SEAGrid helps scientist create model inputs, simplifies access to computing resources, enables visualizations of outputs, and provides archives for simulation data.
fields.feature_1_text: Optimize and characterize molecular and periodic structures and predict thermodynamics and kinetics using computational chemistry applications using Ab initio, Semi-empirical, Force-field based codes such as Gaussian, Gamess, Tinker, DFTB+.
fields.feature_2_text: Time evolution of large material and biological systems to predict dynamic structural and energetic characteristics using Applications such as Lammps, Amber, NAMD using mostly empirical force fields including reaction force fields.
fields.feature_3_text: Finite element analysis of engineering structures and components for modeling static and low-speed dynamic events both in the time and frequency domain using applications such as Abaqus.
fields.feature_4_text: Modeling flow of gases and liquids under various conditions using applications such as Nek5000 and OpenFOAM.
fields.custom_body_message: For a full list of current SEAGrid supported applications and computing resources, see SEAGrid Applications.

fields.body:
[{"type": "paragraph_block", "value": {"custom_class": "", "body": "

The SEAGrid science gateway is led by Dr. Sudhakar Pamidighantam and powered by the NSF-funded SciGaP project. This gateway is an agile platform suitable for both research and teaching in science and engineering disciplines.

Bio: Dr. Pamidighantam is a senior member of the Science Gateways Research Center at Indiana University. Dr. Pamidighantam had been a senior research scientist at NCSA at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign supporting computational chemistry and science gateways development in support of molecular sciences faculty. He serves XSEDE organization as an ECSS consultant and conducts research in computational chemistry. See here for Dr. Pamidighantam\u2019s Google Scholar profile.

Usage: SEAGrid has been in operation since 2005 and serves more than 600 scientists and students under 320 projects. Over this time, SEAGrid has supported and enabled more than 120 publications, 50 conference presentations, at least 13 graduate MS and Ph.D. theses. Since April 2015, SEAGrid has served close to 11M XD SUs to support almost 25,000 jobs.

Support: SEAGrid currently supported by NSF Grant #1339774. Previous NSF support includes awards The SEAGrid gateway is a production community cyberinfrastructure resource developed under the NSF Middleware Initiative (NMI: Deployment) grant and supported by additional advanced support through XSEDE ASTA and ECSS program activities. An OGCE [5] project funded by NSF enabled the SEAGrid gateway to adapt sustainable middleware.

Cite:

Citing SEAGrid in academic papers helps us show impact. If you use SEAGrid in your research please help by including the following citation information and acknowledgement in your paper.

SEAGrid (http:www.seagrid.org)[*] is acknowledged for computational resources and services for the selected results used in this publication.

* (a) S. Pamidighantama, S Nakandala, E. Abeysinghe, C Wimalasena, S. Rathnayakae, S. Marru, M. Pierce, Community Science Exemplars in SEAGrid Science Gateway: Apache Airavata Based Implementation of Advanced Infrastructure, Procedia Computer Science Volume 80, 2016, Pages 1927\u20131939

(b) N. Shen, Y. Fan, S. Pamidighantam, E-Science Infrastructures for Molecular Modeling and Parametrization, Journal of Computational Science 5 (2014), pp. 576-589; DOI information: 10.1016/j.jocs.2014.01.005

(c) R. Dooley, K. Milfeld, C. Guiang, S. Pamidighantam, G. Allen, From Proposal to Production: Lessons Learned Developing the Computational Chemistry Grid Cyberinfrastructure, Journal of Grid Computing, 2006, 4, 195-208.

(d) K. Milfeld, C. Guiang, S. Pamidighantam, J. Giuliani. Cluster Computing through an Application-oriented Computational Chemistry Grid. Proceedings of the 2005 Linux Clusters: The HPC Revolution, Apr. 2005.

(e) This work used the Extreme Science and Engineering Discovery Environment (XSEDE), which is supported by National Science Foundation grant number OCI-1053575.

Get BibTex

fields.top_body:
SEAGrid Portal Vs GridChem Desktop Client

SEAGrid Gateway has evolved from initial focus in Chemistry (GridChem) encompassing broader Science and Engineering Applications. In addition to the desktop client, SEAGrid provides a Web Browser based gateway access. The SEAGrid gateway is in active development and we welcome you to try the pre-production alpha release and provide feedback.

Note: For production usage, we recommend using the GridChem Desktop client.

ICCS 2017 International Conference on Computational Science

[{"type": "bootstrap_card", "value": {"card_width": 18, "is_card_img": true, "card_img": 8, "card_img_width": null, "card_img_height": null, "card_title": "Principal Investigator", "card_text": "

Dr. Sudhakar Pamidighantam

Contact: pamidigs@iu.edu

", "card_bg_color": "bg-light", "card_text_color": "text-dark", "btn_text": "Visit my Site", "btn_color": "btn-primary", "btn_link": "https://www.google.com", "custom_class": "mt-4 mx-auto col-md-2"}, "id": "65a2f93a-9e02-42f5-a7b5-8b69e459d1d2"}, {"type": "paragraph_block", "value": {"custom_class": "mt-4 col-md-8 mx-auto", "body": "

The SEAGrid science gateway is led by Dr. Sudhakar Pamidighantam and powered by the NSF-funded SciGaPproject. This gateway is an agile platform suitable for both research and teaching in science and engineering disciplines.

Bio: Dr. Pamidighantam is a senior member of the Science Gateways Research Center at Indiana University. Dr. Pamidighantam had been a senior research scientist at NCSA at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign supporting computational chemistry and science gateways development in support of molecular sciences faculty. He serves XSEDE organization as an ECSS consultant and conducts research in computational chemistry. See here for Dr. Pamidighantam\u2019s Google Scholar profile.

Usage: SEAGrid has been in operation since 2005 and serves more than 600 scientists and students under 320 projects. Over this time, SEAGrid has supported and enabled more than 120 publications, 50 conference presentations, at least 13 graduate MS and Ph.D. theses. Since April 2015, SEAGrid has served close to 11M XD SUs to support almost 25,000 jobs.

Support: SEAGrid currently supported by NSF Grant #1339774. Previous NSF support includes awards The SEAGrid gateway is a production community cyberinfrastructure resource developed under the NSF Middleware Initiative (NMI: Deployment) grant and supported by additional advanced support through XSEDE ASTA and ECSS program activities. An OGCE [5] project funded by NSF enabled the SEAGrid gateway to adapt sustainable middleware.

Cite:

Citing SEAGrid in academic papers helps us show impact. If you use SEAGrid in your research please help by including the following citation information and acknowledgement in your paper.

SEAGrid (http:www.seagrid.org)[*] is acknowledged for computational resources and services for the selected results used in this publication.

* (a) S. Pamidighantama, S Nakandala, E. Abeysinghe, C Wimalasena, S. Rathnayakae, S. Marru, M. Pierce, Community Science Exemplars in SEAGrid Science Gateway: Apache Airavata Based Implementation of Advanced Infrastructure, Procedia Computer Science Volume 80, 2016, Pages 1927\u20131939

(b) N. Shen, Y. Fan, S. Pamidighantam, E-Science Infrastructures for Molecular Modeling and Parametrization, Journal of Computational Science 5 (2014), pp. 576-589; DOI information: 10.1016/j.jocs.2014.01.005

(c) R. Dooley, K. Milfeld, C. Guiang, S. Pamidighantam, G. Allen, From Proposal to Production: Lessons Learned Developing the Computational Chemistry Grid Cyberinfrastructure, Journal of Grid Computing, 2006, 4, 195-208.

(d) K. Milfeld, C. Guiang, S. Pamidighantam, J. Giuliani. Cluster Computing through an Application-oriented Computational Chemistry Grid. Proceedings of the 2005 Linux Clusters: The HPC Revolution, Apr. 2005.

(e) This work used the Extreme Science and Engineering Discovery Environment (XSEDE), which is supported by National Science Foundation grant number OCI-1053575.

[{"type": "bootstrap_card", "value": {"card_width": 18, "is_card_img": true, "card_img": 11, "card_img_width": null, "card_img_height": null, "card_title": "XSEDE", "card_text": "

XSEDE is a single virtual system that scientists can use to interactively share computing resources, data and expertise. People around the world use these resources and services \u2014 things like supercomputers, collections of data and new tools \u2014 to improve our planet.

", "card_bg_color": "bg-light", "card_text_color": "", "btn_text": "Visit the site", "btn_color": "btn-success", "btn_link": "https://www.xsede.org/", "custom_class": "mt-4 col-md-2 mx-auto"}, "id": "5bd11fe1-d7dc-4d43-968c-cf1a8bdbe0fb"}, {"type": "bootstrap_jumbotron", "value": {"title": "Apache Airavata", "body": "

Apache Airavata, a software framework to executing and managing computational jobs on
distributed computing resources including local clusters, supercomputers, national grids,
academic and commercial clouds.

Airavata builds on general concepts of service oriented computing,
distributed messaging, and workflow composition and orchestration. Airavata bundles a server package
with an API, client software development Kits and a general purpose reference UI implementation - Apache Airavata PHP reference gateway.

", "button_text": "Visit the site", "button_link": "https://github.com/apache/airavata", "button_color": "btn-warning", "button_size": "btn-lg", "custom_class": "mt-4 col-md-8 mx-auto"}, "id": "dece2ba1-595f-46ae-bb41-e5ae5dd90c3e"}]

[{"type": "bootstrap_button", "value": {"button_text": "Available applications", "button_link": "https://django.seagrid.org/admin/#/", "button_color": "btn-success", "button_size": "btn-lg", "custom_class": "mx-auto"}, "id": "8a8d4a5d-d972-4add-8777-7c7e75c7a3b0"}, {"type": "paragraph_block", "value": {"custom_class": "col-md-12 text-center", "body": "

Features

The Science and Engineering Applications Grid (SEAGrid) empowers researchers to easily use scientific applications deployed across a wide range of supercomputers, campus clusters, and computing cloud. SEAGrid features both a powerful desktop client and go-anywhere Web application. SEAGrid helps scientist create model inputs, simplifies access to computing resources, enables visualizations of outputs, and provides archives for simulation data.

"}, "id": "ceca43aa-532f-4120-9994-d82cca1b69a1"}]

[{"type": "bootstrap_card", "value": {"card_width": 21, "is_card_img": true, "card_img": 1, "card_img_width": 64, "card_img_height": 64, "card_title": "Computational Chemistry", "card_text": "

Optimize and characterize molecular and periodic structures and predict thermodynamics and kinetics using computational chemistry applications using Ab initio, Semi-empirical, Force-field based codes such as Gaussian, Gamess, Tinker, DFTB+.

", "card_bg_color": "bg-light", "card_text_color": "", "btn_text": "", "btn_color": "", "btn_link": "", "custom_class": "col-md-3 new-home-card"}, "id": "9eb2fcbc-a0ef-4118-8996-003c5c83a154"}, {"type": "bootstrap_card", "value": {"card_width": 21, "is_card_img": true, "card_img": 6, "card_img_width": 64, "card_img_height": 64, "card_title": "Molecular Dynamics (MD)", "card_text": "

Time evolution of large material and biological systems to predict dynamic structural and energetic characteristics using Applications such as Lammps, Amber, NAMD using mostly empirical force fields including reaction force fields.

", "card_bg_color": "bg-light", "card_text_color": "", "btn_text": "", "btn_color": "", "btn_link": "", "custom_class": "col-md-3 new-home-card"}, "id": "4393fe0a-cf6f-466b-9cb8-b2d6a84dfaf9"}, {"type": "bootstrap_card", "value": {"card_width": 21, "is_card_img": true, "card_img": 5, "card_img_width": 64, "card_img_height": 64, "card_title": "Structural Mechanics", "card_text": "

Finite element analysis of engineering structures and components for modeling static and low-speed dynamic events both in the time and frequency domain using applications such as Abaqus.

", "card_bg_color": "bg-light", "card_text_color": "", "btn_text": "", "btn_color": "", "btn_link": "", "custom_class": "col-md-3 new-home-card"}, "id": "1dc1cb69-3e25-41b4-b666-a623cf46ef18"}, {"type": "bootstrap_card", "value": {"card_width": 21, "is_card_img": true, "card_img": 2, "card_img_width": 64, "card_img_height": 64, "card_title": "Fluid Dynamics", "card_text": "

Modeling flow of gases and liquids under various conditions using applications such as Nek5000 and OpenFOAM.

", "card_bg_color": "bg-light", "card_text_color": "", "btn_text": "", "btn_color": "", "btn_link": "", "custom_class": "col-md-3 new-home-card"}, "id": "186c0def-cbbd-4113-ac07-2811656ae096"}]
